header.title: Manipulation Through Astral Correspondences: How to Define, Create and use Telesmatic Images in Ritual MagicK
keywords: Hermetic Order Of The Golden Dawn

central_thesis: The central thesis is that Telesmatic Images, formulated by synthesizing descriptive attributions of Hebrew letters from a name or force, provide a potent and symbolically correct method for defining, creating, and using visual representations of entities (angels, demons, elementals, or abstract ideas) within ritual magic, enabling effective invocation, evocation, and connection across the Kabbalistic Four Worlds.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces Telesmatic Images as a method to formulate the image of any entity based on its Hebrew name, aiding in identifying proper Astral Images for invocation and evocation. It highlights the technique's obscurity, its origin in two papers from the Adepti Minores of The Hermetic Order Of The Golden Dawn, and its importance to Western and Kabbalistic magical traditions.

Part 1 defines a Telesmatic Image as a pictorial formulation of a Force, built by combining Hebrew letter attributions, colors, and traditional symbolism. It emphasizes precise construction to avoid imperfection when dealing with 'Angelic and higher Potencies.' The text delineates the applicability of Telesmatic Images to the Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetzirah, Assiah), noting they primarily correlate to Yetzirah. It also details how the 'sex' of an image is determined by the predominance of masculine or feminine letter tendencies and traditional knowledge, with specific rules for attributing body parts to the letters in a name (first letter = head, final letter = feet, middle letters = torso/members).

Part 2 provides tabulated information essential for forming Telesmatic Images. This includes the Hebrew Alphabet with Latin equivalents, numerical values, final meanings, and attributes (gender, physical traits, temperament). It also lists Divine Names, Archangelic Names, and Choir of Angels attributed to each of the Ten Sephiroth across the Four Worlds, along with their respective King, Queen, Emperor, and Empress Colour Scales.

Part 3 offers practical examples of formulating Telesmatic Images. It illustrates the process for an Angelic Force of the Order of SERAPHIM (Yetziratic World), Archangel SANDALPHON (Briatic World), the Goddess DIANA (testing the formula in a different tradition, related to Yetzirah), and Archangel RAPHAEL (Briatic World). Each example describes the entity's visual characteristics, colors, and symbolic elements derived from its Hebrew name and traditional correspondences, demonstrating how the theory translates into a concrete visual form while adhering to traditional gender and nature of the Force.

Part 4 outlines the practical application of Telesmatic Images in ritual magic. It describes two main methods for incorporating images into Talismanic Magic (visualizing light rays onto a talisman or the image 'standing' upon it) and their use in Path Working. The text also explains how to use Telesmatic Images for attaining contact with Angelic Forces or Sephiroth and 'assuming the forms.' A detailed method for formulating corresponding incenses is provided, where ingredients are chosen based on the Hebrew letters in the entity's name, with each ingredient in equal proportion per letter.

Part 5 details the method for extracting a Sigil of any name using the Hermetic Rose. It specifies that every Sigil has a Primary and Secondary Sigil, recommending the use of existing Primary Sigils if available. Although the method for extracting planetary sigils from planetary squares is omitted, the Hermetic Rose is presented as the primary tool for creating sigils from the 22 Hebrew Letters when an existing primary sigil cannot be found.

key_concepts.definition: A pictorial formulation of a Force, built by combining the descriptive attributions of Hebrew letters composing the Name of the Force, its attributed colors, and other traditional symbolism, resulting in a composite Image representative of the inherent nature of the Force, symbolically correct and MagicKaly potent.

The Kabbalistic planes of existence: Atziluth (Archetypal, Deific Names), Briah (Creative, Archangels), Yetzirah (Formative, Angelic Orders), and Assiah (Material, Elements, Planets, Humans, Qlippoth). Telesmatic Images primarily apply to the World of Yetzirah, though they can be adapted for Briah in a 'shadowy' sense.

Specific qualities (e.g., gender, physical features, temperament, elemental, planetary, zodiacal potencies) assigned to each of the 22 Hebrew Letters, derived from 'Sepher Yetzirah' and used as building blocks for Telesmatic Images.

The 'sex' of a Telesmatic Image is determined by the predominance of Masculine or Feminine tendencies in its constituent Hebrew letters, combined with any traditional knowledge of the Force's nature. Tradition also dictates masculine gender for vehement/rushing forces and feminine for firm/steady forces.

A specific rule for constructing the visual image: the first letter of the entity's name represents the head, the final letter describes the feet, and the middle letters represent the torso and other members of the figure.
A symbolic design representing a name or force, intended to be emblazoned upon the chest of a Telesmatic Image or used independently as a magical device.
A magical diagram used to extract a Sigil of any name from the 22 Hebrew Letters, particularly useful when traditional or primary sigils for an entity are not available.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a method for creating 'Telesmatic Images' (visual representations) of magical forces. This involves taking a Hebrew name (of an angel, demon, idea, etc.), breaking it down into individual letters, and then attributing specific qualities (gender, physical features, colors, elemental/planetary/zodiacal associations) to each letter based on established Kabbalistic correspondences. These attributes are then synthesized to form a composite image, with the first letter dictating the head, the last letter the feet, and middle letters the torso. The generated image is then used in various ritual contexts. The system also includes instructions for creating corresponding incenses by mixing ingredients associated with each letter in the name and for deriving sigils using the Hermetic Rose.

Hebrew Alphabet and its attributions (gender, physical, elemental, planetary, zodiacal)

relevant_quotes.text: A Telesmatic Image is a pictorial formulation of a Force which can be built up by combining the descriptive attributions of the Hebrew letters composing the Name of the Force, the colors attributed thereto and other traditional symbolism; the synthesis of the devices producing a composite Image representative of the inherent nature of the Force, symbolically correct and MagicKaly potent.

When formulating a Telesmatic Image one must take into account the particular Force's traditional place in the scheme of Creation. Deities are allocated to the Archetypal World of ATZILUTH. Great Cosmic Forces, known as Archangels, belong to the creative world of BRIAH. Formative potencies, termed as Angels, are allocated to the Formative World of YETZIRAH. Expressive Forces, example: Planetary Powers, Elemental Spirits and human beings, exist in the World of Action known as ASSIAH.

When constructing a Telesmatic Image, the first letter of the Name shall represent the features of the HEAD of the figure, and the final letter shall describe the FEET; the middle letters representing the torso and members.

It is to be remembered that there are Angels of Death and Disease, that may reflect into its Image, and that there are Demons of Love and agriculture Not all angels are beautiful beings, also not all Demons are hideous or sexual
This technique is universal, manifested in the physical through the Kabbalah and its relation to the Hebrew language and Names.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism, especially for practitioners of Qabalah and Golden Dawn-derived systems. It provides a structured, systematic, and practical methodology for constructing and utilizing magical images, a fundamental component of ritual magic. By detailing the letter-by-letter attribution process, it offers a deep dive into an often-overlooked aspect of magical practice. Its emphasis on precision in formulation and understanding the hierarchy of the Four Worlds ensures that practitioners approach magical operations with a solid theoretical and practical foundation, preventing 'contamination' and ensuring efficacy.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of intermediate to advanced practitioners of Western Esotericism, including Qabalists, Hermetic magicians, and followers of the Golden Dawn tradition. It assumes prior familiarity with Hebrew letters, Kabbalistic concepts (Sephiroth, Four Worlds), and basic magical theory. While the author makes an effort to demystify the technique, the technical depth and specific terminology require a foundational understanding of occult principles, making it less suitable for absolute beginners.
